questions.question:
Question 1: The following finding was noted on the cardiac tissue specimen of an 82-year-old man. Which 
of the following is false about the given finding?

options.a: It is a tell-tale sign of free radical injury
options.b: It is injurious to the cell and its function
options.c: It is derived through lipid peroxidation
options.d: It can also be seen in liver of aging patients

questions.explanation:
The given histopathological image shows yellow-brown lipochrome or lipofuscin pigment. It is not 
injurious to the cell or its functions. 53 
Sold by @itachibot Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment derived from the peroxidation of lipids of subcellular 
membranes. It is an indicator of free radical injury to the cells. It is an insoluble, brownish yellow, granular intracellular material that is seen in the liver, 
brain, and heart due to normal aging. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a 
characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy. It can also be seen in patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

questions.question:
Question 2: A pathologist is examining a liver biopsy specimen from a patient with liver disease. The 
following finding is noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding? 47 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given histopathological image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis along with 
intraparenchymal cholestasis, which is suggestive of fatty liver. This condition can occur due 
to alcoholism. The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on 
hematoxylin and eosin staining. 54 
Sold by @itachibot A few causes of fatty liver are as follows: • Alcoholism - most common cause in developed countries • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) - associated with diabetes and obesity • Toxins • Malnutrition • Dyslipidemia • Anoxia Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism. It 
may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys. The most common form of lipid accumulation is triglycerides. Other forms of lipid that can be 
accumulated include cholesterol, cholesterol esters, and phospholipids. 55 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following conditions are associated with the intracellular accumulation of 
cholesterol and cholesterol esters?
questions.explanation:
Fabry disease and abetalipoproteinemia are not associated with intracellular accumulations of 
cholesterol and/or cholesterol esters. The following conditions are associated with the intracellular accumulation of cholesterol and/or 
cholesterol esters: • Xanthomas - accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the subepithelial connective tissue of 
the skin and in tendons • Strawberry gallbladder (cholesterolosis) - accumulation of cholesterol-laden macrophages in the 
lamina propria of the gallbladder • Niemann–Pick disease type C - mutations in NPC1 or NPC2 gene results in impaired cholesterol 
transport inside the cells • Atherosclerosis - foamy macrophages in the tunica intima of smooth muscles

questions.question:
Question 4: A 60-year-old male patient presented with backache. Urine examination revealed nephrotic 
range proteinuria with Bence-Jones proteins. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia. 
Histopathological examination of the bone marrow aspirate showed the findings as given 
below. The findings seen on histopathology are due to the accumulation of: 48 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing Russell bodies are suggestive 
of multiple myeloma. These are globular, eosinophilic intracellular accumulations of 
immunoglobulins. 56 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 36-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism presented with increasing abdominal 
girth and malaise. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was 6 cm. 
Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic 
inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. In this condition, there are 
intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies. They are composed 
of intermediate keratin filaments. Mallory bodies are also seen in the following conditions: • Morbid obesity • Indian childhood cirrhosis • Wilson’s disease • Primary biliary cirrhosis 57 
Sold by @itachibot There are several types of cytoskeletal proteins such as microtubules, thin actin filaments, thick 
myosin filaments, and intermediate filaments (10 nm). The intermediate filaments provide a flexible intracellular scaffold that organizes the cytoplasm 
and resists the forces applied to the cell. They are divided into five classes: • Keratin filaments - characteristic of epithelial cells (forms Mallory Denk bodies) • Neurofilaments - neurons (forms neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease) • Desmin filaments - muscle cells • Vimentin filaments - connective tissue cells • Glial filaments - astrocytes

questions.question:
Question 6: An elderly man diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung underwent surgical 
resection. Histopathological examination of the resected hilar lymph nodes revealed the 
following finding as given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this? 49 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological image of the lymph node showing abundant 
black-colored pigment within the macrophages are characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis. The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are 
engulfed by the lung macrophages and then transported to the hilar lymph nodes, which causes 
the blackening of the tissues. The carbon dust may also induce fibroblastic reaction or 
emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis. It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with 
carbon particles, such as coal mines. 58 
Sold by @itachibot Anthracotic pigmentation - Pulmonary anthracosis Anthracotic pigmentation - Pulmonary anthracosis The following images show the accumulation of various types of pigments within cells. 59 
Sold by @itachibot Hemosiderin pigrrient íVìela n tin pigment Lipoch rots ec ac Umulatiora in curdi ac inyocyte 60 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left 
arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending 
artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Atheromatous plaques are associated with dystrophic calcification. This is seen in the presence 
of normal calcium levels in the serum. The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it 
occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type. Some examples include atheromas 
of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis.

questions.question: Question 8: In which of the following patients would you not expect metastatic calcification?

options.b: A 75-year-old woman suffering from multiple myeloma

questions.explanation:
Tuberculosis is associated with dystrophic calcification in the areas of caseous necrosis, not 
metastatic calcification. Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues in the presence of hypercalcemia. Causes of 
hypercalcemia include Paget's disease, malignancy, and sarcoidosis. Metastatic calcification can occur throughout the body, but it mainly affects: • Interstitial tissues of the vasculature • Kidneys • Lungs • Gastric mucosa The calcium deposits morphologically resemble those described in dystrophic calcification. 
Although they generally do not cause clinical dysfunction, extensive calcifications in the lungs may 
be evident on radiographs and may produce respiratory distress. Massive deposits in the kidney 
(nephrocalcinosis) can lead to renal damage.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following stains is not used in the detection of calcium in tissues?
questions.explanation:
The Congo red stain is used for staining amyloid bodies, not calcium. The following staining techniques are used for calcium: • Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) - • Calcium forms a blue-black lake with hematoxylin • Azan stain - • Used to distinguish osteoid from the mineralized bone • Alizarin red S stain - 61 
Sold by @itachibot • Forms an orange-red lake with calcium • Works best with small amounts of calcium • An example is Michaelis–Gutmann (MG) bodies, seen in malakoplakia • Von Kossa method - • Useful for tissues containing large amounts of phosphates and carbonates, such as bone • Silver ions react with phosphate in the presence of acidic material • Silver phosphate gets degraded to silver in presence of light, giving black color • MG bodies also stain with von kossa stain. The image given below demonstrates MG bodies which are seen in malakoplakia using the Von 
Kossa stain. 62 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following stains is used for staining melanin?
questions.explanation:
Masson–Fontana stain is used to stain melanin, a brown-black endogenous pigment. The following different staining techniques are used for melanin: • Dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA)-oxidase method - • Most specific method • DOPA-oxidase acts on DOPA in the melanin-producing cells to produce a brownish-black 
deposit as shown below • Masson Fontana stain - • Used to stain melanin and argentaffin granules in neuroendocrine cells (e.g. carcinoid syndrome) • It stains melanin black, as shown below 63 
Sold by @itachibot • Schmorl’s method - stains melanin blue-green, as shown below

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is responsible for an increased incidence of cancer in old age?
questions.explanation:
Increased incidence of cancer in old age is due to telomerase reactivation. Normally, with every cell division, there is some shortening of telomeres at the ends of 
chromosomes. Once the telomeres are shortened beyond a certain point, it may cause cell-cycle 
arrest or apoptosis. This is called replicative senescence. Telomerase is the enzyme that prevents the shortening of telomeres. This enzyme is usually 
present in germ cells but is absent in most somatic cells. Abnormal reactivation of telomerase in somatic cells leads to evasion of senescence and apoptosis. 
It enables the cells to divide several times than normal.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is false regarding sirtuins?
questions.explanation:
Sirtuins are responsible for an increase in insulin sensitivity. Hence, it can play an important role 
in the treatment of diabetes. Sirtuins are a class of proteins that possess either mono-ADP-ribosyltransferase or deacylase 
activity. They have been shown to slow down the aging process. Calorie restriction and intake of 
red wine are associated with an increase in sirtuin levels. Sirtuins act by the following mechanisms: • Inhibition of the metabolic activity • Reduction in apoptosis • Stimulation of protein folding 64 
Sold by @itachibot • Inhibition of free radical damage • Increased insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism • Ensure that damaged DNA is not propagated, preventing the accumulation of mutations • Promotes replicative senescence under chronic stress

questions.question: Question 13: Which fixation technique is used for fat in the histopathological examination?
questions.explanation:
A frozen section is done for the fixation of fats. This ensures that the tissue need not go through 
routine processing, which can remove lipids. When the tissue sample goes through rapid freezing, it becomes firmer. The ice acts as an 
embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned. The temperature range in the cryostat machine usually ranges from 0■C to -35■C. The majority 
of the tissue can be appropriately sectioned between -15■C to -25■C. Tissue samples that contain 
water can be sectioned at a higher temperature. The tissues that contain more fat will need to be 
cut at a lower temperature. The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain. It can identify neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears 
and tissues. It is used in the following conditions: • Fat emboli in lung tissue • Renal cell carcinoma • Sebaceous gland tumors of the skin • Lipid-rich carcinomas Fixatives containing alcohols, or routine processing with clearing, will remove lipids. Fixation can 
be achieved by the following methods: • Physical methods - heating, microwaving, cryopreservation • Chemical methods - immersion of specimen in fixative, perfusing vascular system with a fixative Given below are a few fixatives with their uses: The most commonly used fixative is 10% neutral buffered formalin. Technique/Tissue 
Fixative Electron microscopy 
Glutaraldehyde Trephine biopsy-bone marr 
ow Zenker's fluid (AZF fixative) GI biopsies 
Bouin's fixative Brain 
Formalin ammonium chlorid 
e Adrenal biopsy 
Orth's fluid Pap smear 
Ethanol 65 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 56-year-old diabetic male presented with arthralgia and skin pigmentation. On 
examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly, arthropathy involving small joints, 
excessive skin pigmentation with a characteristic slate-grey hue, and hypogonadism. As a part 
of the work-up, liver biopsy was done. Which of the following stains should be used for 
staining the biopsy specimen?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis in which there is iron overload. The 
excess iron gets deposited in tissues as hemosiderin which can be detected using Perl's Prussian 
blue stain. It is based on the principle of the formation of ferric ferrocyanide, which is blue in color. Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived granular pigment that is golden yellow to brown. It 
accumulates in the tissues when there is a local or systemic excess of iron. Iron is normally stored within cells in association with the protein apoferritin, forming ferritin 
micelles. Large aggregates of these micelles are hemosiderin deposits seen both in light and 
electron microscopy. 66 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A 34-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for premature cataracts, thinning of skin, 
alopecia, osteoporosis, and atherosclerosis. She is found to have a hereditary genetic 
mutation in the WRN gene. This gene encodes which of the following proteins?

options.a: It is a mechanism of innate immunity
options.b: Monocytes and macrophages are mainly involved
options.c: Tissue injury is usually mild and self-limited

questions.explanation:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Werner syndrome, a premature aging disorder. The 
mutated gene encodes a DNA helicase. Werner syndrome is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the WRN gene. This 
gene encodes a protein with multiple DNA-dependent enzymatic functions including: • ATPase • Helicase • Exonuclease DNA helicase is involved in DNA replication and repair. A defect in this enzyme causes 
rapid accumulation of damaged chromosomes that may mimic the injury that normally 
accumulates during cellular aging. Affected persons show various manifestations of premature 
aging including: • Atherosclerosis • Senile cataract • Skin atrophy • Alopecia • Osteoporosis They are also at risk for the development of a variety of cancers. Patients typically die in the 5th 
decade from either cancer or cardiovascular disease. 67 
Sold by @itachibot Acute Inflammation
